title: Wanna write a short story, what do i do with it?
body: so i have been binge reading tons of awesome short stories in the league universe, and some of them are really amazingly written, my personal favourite being 'A Good Death' and has inspired me to have a go at writing something of my own. but what do i do with the story after i write it?

replies.body:
That's really great to hear - I'd love to see more players getting excited by League lore and writing their own stories. I wouldn't have my job right now if I hadn't submitted fan-fiction to Games Workshop in like 2010, which ended up with me being published as a writer, then working for them as an editor, and now being here at Riot... :-)

My advice to you is the same I'd give to anyone. If you want to be a writer, then start writing (and reading!) every day. Read everything you can, fiction and non-fiction, from as many genres and styles as you can. Write anything that you feel inspired to try, and never throw away anything you've written.

Look back at stuff you wrote a week ago, a month ago, whatever. Figure out how to make it better. Re-write it.

When you're comfortable with stuff you've written, post it online for comments from other writers and fans. Join writing clubs. Join book clubs. Find your favorite authors, and read everything they've ever published.

If you decide you'd like to try writing for a living one day, my favorite ever quote/advice about writing comes from Lawrence Kasdan, most famous for his Star Wars work:
_"Being a writer is like having homework every night for the rest of your life."_

Truth.

> [{quoted}](name=Scathlocke,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=qy7yv4GL,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2018-04-12T23:41:01.703+0000)
>
>  If you want to be a writer, then _GET AN EDITOR._

Fixed it for you.  ;)

For people getting started an editor just needs to be a second set of eyes.  You don't have to pay a professional or anything like that.  But you do need someone else critiquing you.  Ideally they know the difference between third person limited and third person omniscient, they can tell you that your first sentence or page is weak, they can identify plot holes and pacing issues, etc.  However if all you have is someone who told you that he got bored by the 4th paragraph and stopped reading, that's fine too because you now know your intros are boring.  

Getting better in general requires failing and learning why you failed.  Writers really need that second set of eyes to pick out their failures.

This is great advice.

It's also worth getting as many people as you can (whose opinion you trust/value) to read it. Non-writers will give different feedback from writers, League players will have more specific knowledge than non-gamers... and any/all feedback is useful, in that it shows you what a random person WILL think, somewhere out there, even if it was an angle you never, ever would have dreamed of!

But yes - if you happen to know an editor who owes you a favour or two, rope them in as early as possible ;-)

Hi Scathlocke,

On the topic of fanfiction rewrites, I've done some solid edits to my contest story, because I really want it to be perfect or at least better than what the word limit allowed it to be. Can I share them? I never asked, but will there be a future for the Narrative winning entries? Are any of you lore folks open to discussing that future?

I would love to write more!
We're certainly open to discussing that. Speak to your contact at Riot from the contest, and ask if you can be connected with Ariel and Laurie by email. :-)
Publish that bad boy on your blog/website/whatever or post it here on boards, or both. We love a good fic.

Wait... two years ago, AntInOz and Jaredan both said that the company couldn't read fan fiction because of legal reasons (they might steal ideas that could lead to copyright problems...)

Now, it's okay, that the team now enjoys a good fan-fic?  What changed, if anything?

So... both AntInOz and Jaredan were certainly correct at the time, and in principle now too. Narrative Rioters will not generally engage with/read fan-fiction in any official capacity, and certainly won't be able to offer any creative feedback.

I'm not sure about "can't" read, but certainly we usually _wouldn't_, unless it was a speculative submission made during an open call for such content (like the recent creative contest) which we were expected to read and assess. But I do think using words like "steal" and "copyright" gives a rather misleading view of the situation, or anybody's intentions. I don't know where/when the guys talked about fan-fiction, but I imagine they just wanted to keep things simple for everyone involved. :-)
Kinda depressing to think even if we write amazing fanfiction, the writers of the original stuff won't read whatever we write. :(

If we post the story with explicitly stating that we are knowingly and willingly giving full rights to Riot to copy/modify/sell any components of the story and that all characters, based from League of Legends or not, are not our property? It's always fun to see what the pros think of your work and where the strengths and weaknesses are.

Basically: How do we get Senpai to notice?
I believe when they said the company, they probably meant them in general at the time. That Narrative group that is.

Well, by here Carnival probably means the "[Concepts and Creations](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/skin-champion-concepts)" Board, just in case you decided to take the plunge :)  I always feel bad when folks post them here in the "Story, Art, & Sound" Board (which is an easy mistake to make).

wow, so great to see so many replies from the people at riot!
right now im just gathering information and thinking up concepts for a story, and i'm definitely gonna share it on the boards when im happy with what i got : ^)

I was thinking about posting my own about Karthus and basing the story around a plot derived from "The Lightbringer" PentaKill song. I've gotten a lot done with it so far. Now I just need to convince myself it's worthy of being posted.

 {{sticker:sg-lulu}} 


Anyway, best of luck to you. Find something that sticks in your head then let your imagination run wild, structure it, rationalize what needs to be rationalized, then go for it.



Edit: Fuck it, Imma do it. Once my courses wrap up and I can proof read everything at the end of this month. I'm actually pretty hyped about going through the story and changing some stuff (and trying not to add more and more to make it a novel).

You can post it as a fanfiction (as long as you give recognition to Riot for the characters/world/lore/ecc.) on any site built to host them, such as Fanfiction.net or ArchiveOfOurOwn.org

My only suggestion is to try and do your homework first: study the places and the characters you want to write about, so that you can get close to what is canon as much as possible: if for example you make a story about Yasuo and the character you wrote is no similar at all to what we know of him from in-game quotes and Riot's stories/biographies, then of Yasuo he would have only the name; different story if you set it as an Alternate Universe, but that's like taking the easy way out unless you set it up properly and in a "realistic" way
